noun.description: A piece of ordnance with a relatively short barrel, used to fire stones and (in early use) broken iron, case-shot, etc., in naval and siege warfare.

origin: Late 16th century; earliest use found in Robert Barrett (fl. ?1586–1607), soldier and author. From Spanish pedrero piece of artillery (late 1520s in cañon pedrero) from post-classical Latin petrarium. Compare Catalan pedrer, Portuguese pedreiro, Italian petriero, petriere; compare also perrier and further Romance cognates cited s.v.
